data.text: The Vaude Aqua Panniers I had fell apart. The fabric failed and developed holes where the panniers had creased when rolling them up to close. Waterproof zips failed in the pockets. All within two years. VAude were a nightmare to deal with. Have bought Ortlieb panniers since, several sets and colours and not a single problem.
data.author: Alex Maudorn

data.text: Decathlon has ortlieb-alikes for a fraction of the money so if you're about to use them lightly they should be fine. (But thanks, I'm keeping my 20+ years old ortliebs)

data.text: Yea drop the price ceiling or the waterproof part, you pick.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Ortliebs are the global gold standard. Arkel and Axiom have some w good reputation but I have no hands-on with (I have some Axiom bags I like, non waterproof). I don't prefer full waterproof due to gradual buildup of interior funk; I usually get water-resistant then use actual dry bags as internal pannier organizers a well as waterproof prtection for the items that require that. Saves a few $$ sometimes, but really is a layered approach that I have experience as a sailor as being long-term effective. IMHO. Good luck whichever way you go. Arkel has something they call Dry-Lites for about $100 but less than 40L.
data.author: Mike Bauer

data.text: Carradice!
data.author: Christian Tydecks

data.text: There are lots of alternatives to Ortliebs now. Some would also argue that they are no longer THE gold standard. There are several equally good brands, some with a better aftersales and warrantee service. One thing to watch out for is the rain covers, if you want them. With some panniers they come included, with other panniers they are extra, and some can be very expensive for what they are. Some might ask, 'Why would you want rain covers with waterproof bags?'. Firstly, road mud. Secondly, if you want to stealth camp you will want dull color panniers, however a bright yellow rain cover will make your more visible to drivers on a rainy road.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Vaude
data.author: Ango Radus

data.text: Waterproof is nice. However, I have found having non-waterproof is better. Waterproof panniers seem to have less pockets and such. As well, you cannot add anything or stitch up if there is a tear. I like non-waterproof (water resistant work well) and just use a waterproof cover over. Also, waterproof seem to cost more. I have found many used panniers for a really good price.
data.author: Lee Young-il

data.text: you can patch waterproof with non-waterproof fabric then use waterproofing spray to make it waterproof again.

data.text: I use ortlieb because I got prodeal discounts so I can't speak from experience but Rhinowalk Bike Bags are selling at Amazon for about $55 per bag per a 27L bag and have good reviews

data.text: Organize your gear into silnylon dry bags. Your stuff can't get wet and they come in different colors for simple identification
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: I've bought some canvas Agu bags from marketplace (I think they were about 50 euros) about 6 years ago and patched them up a bit. They came with waterproof covers that were a bit worn. Got some waterproof spray for 10 euros and spray them before every multiple day trip, does the job perfectly. Keep my clothes and sleeping bag in drybags, just in case. Never had an issue. You can spend a ton of money on bags if you want to, but you really don't have to.
data.author: Jessica Kittle

data.text: Be quiet
data.author: Aitor Ruiz

data.text: I found a mint set of Rhode Gear panniers (5 piece) on Facebook Marketplace for $50. They are virtually identical to the ones shown. They are very lightly used, and I am thrilled with them. Point being - at what you want to spend, look for a great deal on used gear instead of buying lower quality new.
